results.abstract: Some experts are questioning whether Russian Mir space station, which has been operating for more than twice its original five-year design life, should continue to be used in wake of docking accident and series of recent breakdowns and problems; National Aeronautics and Space Administration continues preparations and training for Sept flight to Mir, but will weigh whether move is safe and if useful research is still possible; shuttle Atlantis is set to pick up American astronaut Michael Foale and deliver American Wendy Lawrence for four-month stay; photo (M)

headline.main: As Mir's Troubles Raise Questions On Joint Effort, Some Seek an Exit

results.snippet: EVEN as Russian engineers devise ways to repair the battered Mir space station, some experts are wondering if it should continue to be used.     Mir, which has been operating in space for more than twice its original five-year design life, has been...
results.lead_paragraph: EVEN as Russian engineers devise ways to repair the battered Mir space station, some experts are wondering if it should continue to be used. Mir, which has been operating in space for more than twice its original five-year design life, has been showing its age through a series of breakdowns and problems that have been accelerating in recent months. In the latest mishap, an unmanned Progress cargo vessel rammed Mir during a practice redocking on Wednesday, rupturing one of the station's pressurized research modules and knocking out almost half of the station's electrical power.

results.abstract: Space station Mir's new oxygen generator has to be turned off because of overheated cooling line, forcing three crewmen to rely on air canisters that caused fire on space station four months ago (S)

headline.main: New Problem Affects Life On Mir Station

results.snippet: The space station Mir's new oxygen generator had to be turned off yesterday because of an overheated cooling line, forcing the three crewmen to rely on the air canisters that caused a fire on the space station four months ago.    Frank Culbertson,...
results.lead_paragraph: The space station Mir's new oxygen generator had to be turned off yesterday because of an overheated cooling line, forcing the three crewmen to rely on the air canisters that caused a fire on the space station four months ago. Frank Culbertson, director of NASA's shuttle-Mir program, said that the problem was evidently with a valve and that it was unclear how long it would take to fix.

results.abstract: NASA chose Fourth of July for Mars landing because it wanted to give landing festive air; other space spectaculars that fell on noteworthy dates noted (S)

headline.main: Fireworks on Mars, and Other Dates

results.snippet: By accident and design alike, NASA has seen a number of its space spectaculars fall on noteworthy dates.    The first space shuttle mission, in 1981, blasted off on April 12, the same date on which the Soviet astronaut Yuri A. Gagarin 20 years...
results.lead_paragraph: By accident and design alike, NASA has seen a number of its space spectaculars fall on noteworthy dates. The first space shuttle mission, in 1981, blasted off on April 12, the same date on which the Soviet astronaut Yuri A. Gagarin 20 years earlier became the first human to fly into orbit, a huge embarrassment to the United States. Some experts see the date of the shuttle's liftoff as a reflection of the cold-war rivalry between East and West, while others question that explanation, saying countdown troubles made such timing unlikely.

headline.main: Ex-Astronaut Becomes Senior Black Marine

results.snippet: Brig. Gen. Charles F. Bolden Jr., who spent 14 years as an astronaut, was promoted to major general in a ceremony here on Thursday, making him the highest-ranking black officer in the Marine Corps.
results.lead_paragraph: Brig. Gen. Charles F. Bolden Jr., who spent 14 years as an astronaut, was promoted to major general in a ceremony here on Thursday, making him the highest-ranking black officer in the Marine Corps.

results.abstract: Michael Foale, NASA astronaut aboard crippled Russian space station Mir, was chosen in place of another American astronaut dropped from Mir program because he was too tall for Soyuz lifeboat attached to Mir; photo (M)

headline.main: Luck Sent Astronaut to Space Station

results.snippet: Michael Foale, the NASA astronaut aboard the Russian space station Mir, wound up on this troubled mission because of his size.    Another astronaut was supposed to be on Mir now, but he was too tall. So it is Mr. Foale -- a 40-year-old astrophysicist...
results.lead_paragraph: Michael Foale, the NASA astronaut aboard the Russian space station Mir, wound up on this troubled mission because of his size. Another astronaut was supposed to be on Mir now, but he was too tall. So it is Mr. Foale -- a 40-year-old astrophysicist who was born in Britain -- who is working with the Russian crew to maintain life support and figure out how to repair the damage the space station sustained in a June 25 accident.

results.abstract: Columbia space shuttle astronauts James Halsell Jr and Donald Thomas say they would gladly volunteer for trip to Mars; chat briefly with Michael Foale, American astronaut aboard damaged Mir space station (S)

headline.main: Mars Volunteers Abound

results.snippet: If NASA needs a few volunteers to fly to Mars, it need look no further than the crew of the space shuttle Columbia.    ''I'll sign up for the program any day they pass that sign-up sheet around,'' the shuttle commander, James Halsell Jr., said just...
results.lead_paragraph: If NASA needs a few volunteers to fly to Mars, it need look no further than the crew of the space shuttle Columbia. ''I'll sign up for the program any day they pass that sign-up sheet around,'' the shuttle commander, James Halsell Jr., said just before the Mars Pathfinder spacecraft landed on the red planet on Friday.

headline.main: Russia Launches Supply Craft to Repair the Damaged Mir Space Station

results.snippet: A spacecraft crammed with repair equipment and fuel was launched toward the stricken Mir space station this morning, as Russian scientists struggled to save the centerpiece of their space program.    A wave of applause swept through the Mission...
results.lead_paragraph: A spacecraft crammed with repair equipment and fuel was launched toward the stricken Mir space station this morning, as Russian scientists struggled to save the centerpiece of their space program. A wave of applause swept through the Mission Control Center here after the Progress cargo craft blasted off from the Baikonur complex in the former Soviet republic of Kazakstan then separated from its booster.

results.abstract: Robyn Meredith travel article on Detroit, Mich, where nation's largest museum devoted to black history and culture opened this spring; new Museum of African-American History is part of significant group of African-American historical sites in city and within short drive; photos; map (L)

headline.main: In Detroit, Black Pride Where Slaves Once Hid

results.snippet: EARL CALLOWAY, a visitor from Chicago, stood up in the sanctuary of the Second Baptist Church in downtown Detroit and began to sing an impromptu a cappella rendition of ''Live a-Humble,'' an African-American spiritual. ''I want to sing in this...
results.lead_paragraph: EARL CALLOWAY, a visitor from Chicago, stood up in the sanctuary of the Second Baptist Church in downtown Detroit and began to sing an impromptu a cappella rendition of ''Live a-Humble,'' an African-American spiritual. ''I want to sing in this church,'' he explained to the roomful of strangers with him on a tour of the church that served as the last stop on the Underground Railroad for 5,000 slaves on their way to freedom in Canada. Detroit is a powerful draw for anyone interested in African-American history. In the 19th century, it was home to some of the largest ''stations,'' or hiding places, on the Underground Railroad, the network of abolitionists who helped slaves fleeing north to freedom. In this century, waves of African-Americans came from the South to work in the city's auto factories. In the 1960's, Detroit spawned the Motown sound, and today, with a population that is 76 percent African-American, it is the nation's largest city with a black majority.

results.abstract: Article describes trees at Grove of Famous and Historic Trees at Lasdon Arboretum in Somers, NY; photos (M)

headline.main: Waving the Flag From Historic Trees

results.snippet: THE fireworks are over, but what can one do if one is still in the mood for a bit of Americana, something to stir feelings of patriotism on this, the Sunday after the Fourth of July?    How about looking at trees? Not just any trees, but specimens...
results.lead_paragraph: THE fireworks are over, but what can one do if one is still in the mood for a bit of Americana, something to stir feelings of patriotism on this, the Sunday after the Fourth of July? How about looking at trees? Not just any trees, but specimens descended directly from specific trees that were standing at specific battle sites during the American Revolution and the Civil War. Or the Betsy Ross Sycamore, grown from seeds shed by a sycamore growing in the yard of the home of the woman who designed the country's flag. Or the John F. Kennedy Yellowwood, a tiny sapling cultivated from the yellowwood that shades Kennedy's grave at Arlington National Cemetery.

results.abstract: Daniel S Goldin, administrator of National Aeronautics and Space Administration, says decision on whether to send replacement NASA astronaut to Russia's troubled Mir space station in Sept will rest on assignment's likelihood of being safe and productive; Navy Comdr Wendy Lawrence is set to replace Michael Foale (S)

headline.main: For Mir Return, Safety Is Called Crucial Factor

results.snippet: The decision on whether to send a replacement NASA astronaut to Russia's troubled Mir space station in September will rest on the assignment's likelihood of being safe and productive, the space agency's administrator said today.    ''There are two...
results.lead_paragraph: The decision on whether to send a replacement NASA astronaut to Russia's troubled Mir space station in September will rest on the assignment's likelihood of being safe and productive, the space agency's administrator said today. ''There are two aspects to sending astronauts up to the Mir space station,'' Daniel S. Goldin, the administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said on the CNN program ''Late Edition.'' ''First, is it safe? And secondly, is there a scientific and technical reason for doing that?''

headline.main: NEWS SUMMARY

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A1-7    A Claim of Victory In Cambodia's Fighting  After two days of armed confrontation, one of Cambodia's two Prime Ministers, the former Communist Hun Sen, claimed victory over the forces of Norodom Ranariddh, his royalist rival...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A1-7 A Claim of Victory In Cambodia's Fighting After two days of armed confrontation, one of Cambodia's two Prime Ministers, the former Communist Hun Sen, claimed victory over the forces of Norodom Ranariddh, his royalist rival and co-Prime Minister. Mr. Hun Sen, who denied that his actions amounted to a coup, accused Prince Ranariddh of illegal acts and wanted him replaced. It was unclear whether the armed confrontation had ended. Prince Ranariddh was abroad, but his party officials said they had not given up. A1 Caribbean Weighs Tie to Britain Across the English-speaking Caribbean, from Barbados to Jamaica, rising dissatisfaction with the handling of death-row cases is leading Governments to weigh proposals to eliminate formal ties to the British legal system. A1 Body May Be Drug Lord The Mexican Government said there were indications that the body of a man who died after plastic surgery was that of Amado Carrillo Fuentes, the billionaire drug trafficker. Although the Government would not completely confirm the drug lord's death, initial tests on the cadaver showed a matching identity. A1 Violence in Northern Ireland The annual march of the Orange Order, a Protestant group, went ahead in a Roman Catholic neighborhood of Northern Ireland after weeks of Government efforts to find a compromise. The police dragged Catholic protesters from the road to clear the way for the parade, and incidents of violence erupted throughout Northern Ireland in response to the decision to allow the march. A3 Pile-Up Kills 62 in Sudan Sixty-two people were killed and 30 seriously injured in a highway pile-up south of Khartoum, the Sudanese capital, state-run television reported. It said a pick-up truck had tried to overtake another car near Kamlin, about 60 miles southeast of the capital, but collided with an oncoming passenger bus and a truck, setting them on fire. Local people tried to put out the blaze with dust and water, as there was no fire station in the area. (Agence France-Presse) Bomb Planted in Moscow An underground Communist group tried to blow up an enormous statue of Peter the Great in Moscow in a protest over a proposal to remove Lenin's body from its mausoleum in Red Square for burial elsewhere, Russian news agencies said. The group, which calls itself the Revolutionary Military Council, said it had planted a bomb but did not detonate it to prevent injuring passers-by. The police defused the device. (Agence France-Presse) Crackdown in Pakistan In a citywide sweep in Karachi, Pakistan, the police arrested 220 people suspected of involvement in a wave of ethnic killings that have left at least 150 people dead in recent months. (AP) Historic Voting in Mexico In San Juan Chamula in the state of Chiapas and across Mexico, voting took place in an election managed for the first time by an autonomous Federal elections council brought about by a reform led by President Ernesto Zedillo. In the race for mayor of Mexico City, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano, an opposition candidate, claimed victory. A1 NATIONAL A8-13, B8 Sojourner Begins a Survey Of Rocks and Soil on Mars The Sojourner, the first mobile explorer of another planet, began prospecting the soil and rocks of Mars and transmitting a flood of data to overjoyed scientists. The roving vehicle pressed the head of one of its scientific instruments to the powdery surface near the Mars Pathfinder and made history as it recorded the surface chemistry. A1 NASA's administrator said the decision on whether to send a replacement NASA astronaut to Russia's troubled Mir space station in September would rest on whether the assignment was judged to be safe and productive. A9 The Hiring of John Huang Congressional investigators say President Clinton took a personal interest in the hiring of John Huang, a fund-raiser whose activities are a central focus of the inquiry into campaign financing improprieties, by the Democratic National Committee, going so far as to ask the committee's finance chairman whether Mr. Huang would be hired. Former party officials have told investigators that in the two months leading up to that conversation, top officials at the White House had strongly urged the Democratic National Committee to hire Mr. Huang so he could begin soliciting contributions from Asian-Americans. A1 A senior Republican Senator investigating campaign-finance abuses urged President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore to testify before the Senate committee that begins its televised hearings on Tuesday. B8 Building in Reagan's Honor The Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center is about to be completed on Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington. Among Federal buildings, the complex is second in size only to the Pentagon. Some say the Reagan Building will save the Government money because $2.2 billion has been spent in rent in the last 60 years to house the Federal offices that will move there. A10 Minister and Poor Against City A flamboyant preacher who favors suspenders and a tie emblazoned with the American flag and the Statue of Liberty goes on trial in Buena Park, Calif., for letting homeless people camp in the parking lot of his First Southern Baptist Church. He faces a maximum of four and a half years in jail for nine misdemeanor charges. A13 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Taking on Soft Money With New Campaign Rules New York City officials are applying new rules intended to limit the influence of unregulated political contributions, known as soft money, in the mayoral race. Records show soft money was more widespread in the last mayoral race than was previously known and suggest it may be hard to curb fund-raising and spending that tries to get around the limits set by the city's Campaign Finance Board. B1 A Local March for Hong Kong Chinese-Americans marched through downtown Manhattan to celebrate the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule. Recent immigrants displayed their affinity to events in China, but protesters in Times Square complained of lingering human-rights abuses in China, cried out for democratic reforms, and said the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule meant more people would come under the control of a corrupt, tyrannical system. B3 Cosby Extortion Trial Opens A trial will open in Manhattan Federal Courthouse for a woman accused of extorting $40 million from Bill Cosby by claiming to be his out-of-wedlock daughter. In pretrial hearings, her lawyers have signaled that they will focus on her belief that he was her father and thus was negotiating her rights as a daughter. B1 Debate on Cameras in Court A debate has erupted in Albany over whether New York should alter or keep its law permitting television cameras in courtrooms, which is considered among the most restrictive in the nation. Some would like to ban television entirely from courtrooms. Others, represented largely by news organizations, like Court TV, want to televise most courtroom proceedings if not all of them. The law gives judges the authority to bar cameras from courtrooms or shield certain witnesses from being filmed while on the stand. B4 SPORTSMONDAY C1-9 Fourth Wimbledon for Sampras Pete Sampras won his fourth Wimbledon championship in five years and his 10th career title in a Grand Slam event, leaving him just two trophies shy of the record. His virtuoso performance against 44th-ranked Cedric Pioline of France demonstrated a perfect and continually perfected grass-court technique. C1 BUSINESS DAY D1-8 '96 Book Sales Plummeted Books went unsold, adult trade sales declined and the shelf life was brief for new titles in 1996, a new study shows. And the book industry itself appears partly to blame. D1 Integrated Services in a Box A company that uses wireless technology to deliver television pictures, phone conversations and Internet access is determined to create the nation's first integrated wireless provider of voice, video and data services. D3 Hitachi Adds Mainframe Power Since Hitachi introduced the Skyline 18 months ago, large companies have snapped them up as fast as Hitachi can make them. The demand has helped Hitachi become the No. 2 mainframe computer maker. D1 Business Digest D1 ARTS C11-15 OBITUARIES B9 Richard H. Randall Jr. An authority on medieval ivory carvings who was director of the Walters gallery in Baltimore was 71. B9 Ade Thomas Milhorat A pioneering researcher of neuromuscular disease and one of the world's foremost experts in muscular dystrophy was 98. B9 Al Braverman A Runyonesque boxing manager and promoter who spent the last two decades working with the promoter Don King was 78. B9 EDITORIAL A14-15 Editorials: Intramural warfare at CUNY; Turkey gets a secular leader; Karl E. Meyer on Tibet. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Anthony Lewis, Bob Herbert. Bridge C12 Crossword C14 Weather D9

results.abstract: Editorial urges Senate panel probing campaign finance abuses not to rush to grant John Huang immunity in exchange for testimony; holds it should not let issue overshadow charge that China illegally spent substantial sums to influence 1996 Presidential and legislative elections (M)

headline.main: Not So Fast on Immunity

results.snippet: John Huang's offer of immunity is enticing, as Senator John Glenn and the Democrats knew it would be. But if not carefully managed it could turn out to be a diversion that would prevent the Governmental Affairs Committee from fully exploring the...
results.lead_paragraph: John Huang's offer of immunity is enticing, as Senator John Glenn and the Democrats knew it would be. But if not carefully managed it could turn out to be a diversion that would prevent the Governmental Affairs Committee from fully exploring the Clinton campaign's Asian money connection. Moreover, it should not be allowed to overshadow the real news of the day, which was Senator Fred Thompson's flat statement that American intelligence sources had established that the Chinese Government spent ''substantial sums of money'' in ways that are ''illegal under U.S. law'' to influence the 1996 Presidential and legislative elections. Mr. Thompson has an obligation to support his conclusion with public testimony. If he does, the United States will have to reassess its dealings with China. The effort of a foreign government to tilt an election is a threat to the integrity of American democracy. It would be hard to imagine President Clinton welcoming China's President, Jiang Zemin, to the White House later this year if the charges are true.

results.abstract: Maureen Dowd Op-Ed column holds Democrats on Senate committee probing campaign finance abuses skillfully and shamelessly outflanked Republicans at first public hearing (M)

headline.main: Face-Off

results.snippet: Bill Clinton should not fret over his legacy. He has done a remarkable job of transforming his party.    The President threw the kitten in the pool and it learned to swim.
results.lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton should not fret over his legacy. He has done a remarkable job of transforming his party. The President threw the kitten in the pool and it learned to swim.

results.abstract: Astronauts aboard space shuttle Columbia conduct more experiments than planned on 12th day of 16-day flight (S)

headline.main: Shuttle Ahead of Schedule

results.snippet: Astronauts on the space shuttle Columbia, in 12 days of a 16-day flight, have already conducted more experiments than planned.    The astronauts have burned more than 165 small fires in Columbia's sealed combustion chambers, ''and we're not done yet,...
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts on the space shuttle Columbia, in 12 days of a 16-day flight, have already conducted more experiments than planned. The astronauts have burned more than 165 small fires in Columbia's sealed combustion chambers, ''and we're not done yet, so I think we're getting over 110 percent of our science output,'' one astronaut, Donald Thomas, said today.

results.abstract: Russian space officials may delay grueling five-hour spacewalk by cosmonauts aboard Mir to repair damaged space station following complaints by commander Vasily Tsibliyev of heartbeat irregularities; repair mission is to restore power lost when 11-year-old space station was hit by cargo vessel (M)

headline.main: Mir Commander's Heart Ills Cast Doubt on Repair Effort

results.snippet: Just days away from a vital mission to repair the stricken Mir space station, the Russian commander said today that he was experiencing heartbeat irregularities.    The apprehensive commander's disclosure was overheard by reporters at the Mission...
results.lead_paragraph: Just days away from a vital mission to repair the stricken Mir space station, the Russian commander said today that he was experiencing heartbeat irregularities. The apprehensive commander's disclosure was overheard by reporters at the Mission Control Center near Moscow. It created a fresh complication for the effort to repair the trouble-plagued Mir and forced Russian space officials to consider delaying the operation.

results.abstract: Science Q&A column explains why video transmissions from space shuttle are very clear, while audio is often scratchy; NASA official blames wireless microphones worn by astronauts, which are designed to be light and unobtrusive; drawing (S)

headline.main: Q&A

results.snippet: Space Talk     Q. Why is it that video from the space shuttle is usually as clear most TV pictures, while audio is nearly as scratchy as transmissions from the 60's?    A. ''It has largely to do with the fidelity of the microphones,'' not the...
results.lead_paragraph: Space Talk Q. Why is it that video from the space shuttle is usually as clear most TV pictures, while audio is nearly as scratchy as transmissions from the 60's? A. ''It has largely to do with the fidelity of the microphones,'' not the quality of space-to-ground communications systems, said John Lawrence, chief of operations and program support for the shuttle at NASA's Johnson Space Center.

results.abstract: Russian Space Agency head Yuri N Koptev suggests Michael Foale, American astronaut aboard Mir, make tricky space walk to repair damaged space station in place of Russian commander Vasily Tsibliyev, who suffers from fatigue and irregular heartbeats, interview; says crew has discussed move and Foale wants to make repairs; NASA officials are skeptical; photos (M)

headline.main: RUSSIANS SUGGEST AMERICAN TAKE ON MIR REPAIR TASK

results.snippet: The head of the Russian Space Agency proposed today that the American astronaut Michael Foale take the place of the Russian commander on the tricky space walk to repair the stricken Mir space station. But NASA officials said they needed to be...
results.lead_paragraph: The head of the Russian Space Agency proposed today that the American astronaut Michael Foale take the place of the Russian commander on the tricky space walk to repair the stricken Mir space station. But NASA officials said they needed to be persuaded of the urgency of the repair before they would allow Mr. Foale to take on the new mission. The proposal came after Russian space officials concluded that Vasily Tsibliyev, the 43-year-old commander of the Mir, was too disabled by fatigue and irregular heartbeats to undertake strenuous repairs this week to restore lost power to the space station.

results.abstract: American space experts see Vasily Tsibliyev, commander of Mir space station, as badly shaken by series of space failures in recent months and intent on avoiding risky repair mission; recall other American and Russian astronauts who have rebelled against Mission Control when faced with heightened risks or tensions (M)

headline.main: On Edge in Outer Space? It Has Happened Before

results.snippet: American space experts say they believe that Vasily Tsibliyev, the commander of the Mir space station, has been badly shaken by a series of space failures in recent months and is intent on avoiding a risky repair mission.    If so, they say, he joins...
results.lead_paragraph: American space experts say they believe that Vasily Tsibliyev, the commander of the Mir space station, has been badly shaken by a series of space failures in recent months and is intent on avoiding a risky repair mission. If so, they say, he joins a little-known roster of astronauts who have rebelled against Mission Control when faced with heightened risks or tensions in exploring space.

headline.main: News Summary

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-9    Russia Requests U.S. Help In Repairing Space Station  The head of the Russian Space Agency proposed that the American astronaut Michael Foale participate in a tricky space walk to repair the stricken Mir space station. The...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Russia Requests U.S. Help In Repairing Space Station The head of the Russian Space Agency proposed that the American astronaut Michael Foale participate in a tricky space walk to repair the stricken Mir space station. The Russian commander has been judged unable to carry out the job because of heart irregularities. NASA officials said they needed to be persuaded of the urgency of the repair before they would allow Mr. Foale to take on the potentially risky mission. A1 Arrest Plan Dropped in Bosnia Plans to capture several prominent Bosnian Serb figures wanted for war crimes from their capital at Pale were abandoned when France declined to join the NATO operation, senior American officials said. Pale is in the French sector, and is the headquarters of the former Bosnian Serb president, Radovan Karadzic, and the former military commander, Ratko Mladic, both of whom have been charged with war crimes. A1

results.abstract: Discussion among members of Senate committee probing 1996 campaign finances focuses on Lippo Group's contributions to Democratic Party and complexity of firm's links to China; photo (M)

headline.main: Campaign Finance Labyrinth Is Obvious, If Not Clear

results.snippet: The moment was more graphic than revealing: On a day when the Republican Senate majority was determined to portray interlocking intrigues between the Riady family's holdings in the Lippo conglomerate and the business interests of China, a chart was...
results.lead_paragraph: The moment was more graphic than revealing: On a day when the Republican Senate majority was determined to portray interlocking intrigues between the Riady family's holdings in the Lippo conglomerate and the business interests of China, a chart was brought forth, seven feet square, to dwarf all previous offerings in what has become a sub-battle of graphics at the campaign finance hearing. The chart, reputedly depicting the growing involvement of the Lippo Group's global interests with Chinese joint ventures, was a massive web-like display of scores of intersecting lines radiating out from a tiny red Chinese flag. The lines connected to dozens of tiny green squares identified in minuscule printing as businesses like the Beijing Tati Turbo Dragon Real Estate Company.

results.abstract: American astronaut Leroy Chiao, part of NASA team that evaluated Russian plan for arduous space walk to repair Mir space station, says plan is technically sound and would not pose excessive risks to American astronaut Michael Foale if he is given task, interview at Russian Mission Control Center, Korolyov; says Foale is prepared to carry out repairs; diagrams (M)

headline.main: U.S. Astronaut Gets Tentative Go to Help Repair Mir

results.snippet: The Russian plan for an arduous space walk to repair the Mir space station is technically sound and would not pose excessive risks to the American member of the crew if he is given the assignment, a team of NASA specialists has concluded.   ...
results.lead_paragraph: The Russian plan for an arduous space walk to repair the Mir space station is technically sound and would not pose excessive risks to the American member of the crew if he is given the assignment, a team of NASA specialists has concluded. ''Technically, I do not see any show-stoppers,'' said Leroy Chiao, an American astronaut dispatched here to assess the Mir repair mission. ''Based on our assessment the risks are manageable.''

results.abstract: Editorial urges NASA to honor Russian request that American astronaut Michael Foale train to help repair Mir space station in place of ailing Russian commander (M)

headline.main: A Rescue Assignment for NASA

results.snippet: The request from Russia that an American astronaut help repair the ailing Mir space station seems well worth honoring. The Russian commander aboard Mir is clearly in no shape, physically or mentally, to perform the repairs, so the head of the Russian...
results.lead_paragraph: The request from Russia that an American astronaut help repair the ailing Mir space station seems well worth honoring. The Russian commander aboard Mir is clearly in no shape, physically or mentally, to perform the repairs, so the head of the Russian space agency has asked that the American astronaut already aboard Mir step in to take his place. It is a risky undertaking, but NASA's own specialists believe the risks are manageable. There is no apparent need to wait until a specially trained Russian crew can ride to the rescue. A fellow space power has asked for American help at a critical time and should get it. Lending a hand would almost certainly improve collaboration on the Mir itself and could foster greater cooperation on more earthbound issues as well. This page has long been skeptical about the need for any manned space stations, given that robots can do space research more cheaply and safely than human astronauts, as the current mission on Mars attests. But American use and support of the Mir station, now in its 11th year of service, is more than a space venture. It provides the chance to collaborate with the Russians and keep their space engineers occupied in peaceful work.

headline.main: NEWS SUMMARY

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-15    Leader at United Nations Unveils Reform Proposals  Secretary General Kofi Annan proposed his plan to streamline the United Nations organizational structure to the General Assembly.   A1    U.S. Moves on Security Council  The...

A1 U.S. Moves on Security Council The Clinton Administration is poised to recommend that three permanent seats on the United Nations Security Council be given to developing nations, a senior American official said. Under the American proposal, developing countries would decide how to fill the new permanent seats. A14

headline.main: News Summary

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-9    Space Station Mir Reels From Loss of Power  Misfortune struck the Russian space ship Mir again when an astronaut accidentally disconnected a cable controlling the guidance system that enables the space station to gather solar...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Space Station Mir Reels From Loss of Power Misfortune struck the Russian space ship Mir again when an astronaut accidentally disconnected a cable controlling the guidance system that enables the space station to gather solar energy. A1 Shots Fired in Bosnia British soldiers in Bosnia fired warning shots and detained four Bosnian Serbs they suspect of having set off explosive charges at a British base in Banja Luka. Bosnian Serb nationalists have waged a low-level harassment campaign against NATO forces, retaliating against their broadened role in apprehending indicted war criminals. A3

results.abstract: Astronaut aboard Mir space station mistakenly disconnects critical cable, disabling guidance system that enables Mir to gather solar energy and causing another crisis for troubled-plagued craft; crew turns off lights and climate-control systems to conserve power; Russian officials refuse to say which astronaut made mistake; say mishap is not life-threatening; NASA announces that it has granted permission for American member of crew, Michael Foale, to train for lengthy space walk to restore power from Mir's Spektr module, which was damaged on June 25 in collision with unmanned cargo craft; diagram; photos (M)

headline.main: ASTRONAUT ERROR DEEPENS ANXIETIES ON SPACE STATION

results.snippet: An astronaut aboard the Mir space station mistakenly disconnected a critical cable today, disabling the guidance system that enables Mir to gather solar energy and causing yet another crisis for the trouble-plagued craft.    Despite the accident,...
results.lead_paragraph: An astronaut aboard the Mir space station mistakenly disconnected a critical cable today, disabling the guidance system that enables Mir to gather solar energy and causing yet another crisis for the trouble-plagued craft. Despite the accident, NASA announced today that it had granted permission for the American member of the crew, Michael Foale, to train for a lengthy space walk to restore power from Mir's Spektr module, which was damaged on June 25 in a collision with an unmanned cargo craft.

results.abstract: Op-Ed article by Yuri Karash disputes those who say Americans should withdraw from involvement in Russian space station Mir because of its many problems; says Mir experiences, even negative ones, have importance for future manned space missions; says it has given participants unique opportunity to learn how to deal with different kinds of emergencies that may happen in orbital outpost (M)

headline.main: What The Mir Can Still Teach Us

results.snippet: As one problem after another strikes the Mir, the voices of alarm are growing louder. Critics of American involvement in the Russian space station see this latest series of troubles -- starting with the serious damage caused by a collision with a...
results.lead_paragraph: As one problem after another strikes the Mir, the voices of alarm are growing louder. Critics of American involvement in the Russian space station see this latest series of troubles -- starting with the serious damage caused by a collision with a cargo ship on June 25 -- as reason for getting the American astronaut on the Mir home safely and then bringing the project to an honorable end. But is this really the wisest course?

results.abstract: Russian space officials say they will probably wait for new crew to arrrive at damaged Mir space station before undertaking space walk to repair it; Mir's string of misfortunes made last few weeks emotionally draining for current crew and ground controllers; new crew would not face same stress (M)

headline.main: 2 1/2-Week Delay in Fixing Mir Seems Likely, Russians Say

results.snippet: Russian space officials said today that they would probably wait for a new crew to arrive at the damaged Mir space station before undertaking a space walk to repair it.    The word came just one day after NASA announced it would allow an American...
results.lead_paragraph: Russian space officials said today that they would probably wait for a new crew to arrive at the damaged Mir space station before undertaking a space walk to repair it. The word came just one day after NASA announced it would allow an American astronaut, Michael Foale, to be trained to perform the complex repair mission, which involves a lengthy space walk.

results.abstract: Russian space officials tell three men aboard Mir space station that they will return to Earth without completing critical repairs to spacecraft, leaving job to fresh crew; Vladimir Solovyov, mission director, says he told astronauts that they were not to blame for collision between Mir module and unmanned cargo ship (S)

headline.main: New Crew to Repair Mir Space Station

results.snippet: Russian space officials today told the three tired men aboard the Mir space station that they would return to Earth without completing critical repairs to the spacecraft, leaving the job to a fresh crew.    The officials told the astronauts in a...
results.lead_paragraph: Russian space officials today told the three tired men aboard the Mir space station that they would return to Earth without completing critical repairs to the spacecraft, leaving the job to a fresh crew. The officials told the astronauts in a 30-minute video link that two Russian astronauts scheduled to arrive at Mir next month would make repairs needed as a result of the collision between Mir's Spektr module an unmanned cargo ship on June 25, when Mir lost much of its power.

results.abstract: Russian officials say they will probably wait until new crew is sent up in Aug before doing space walk to repair damaged Mir space station; photo (M)

headline.main: Mir's Crew Waits in Space For Reinforcements

results.snippet: First a collision damages a module. Then an astronaut unplugs the wrong cable, casting the space station adrift. So last week the crew of Russia's Mir was told to stand down. With so much awry and so much at stake, with nerves frayed and reserves...
results.lead_paragraph: First a collision damages a module. Then an astronaut unplugs the wrong cable, casting the space station adrift. So last week the crew of Russia's Mir was told to stand down. With so much awry and so much at stake, with nerves frayed and reserves depleted, the Russian Space Agency's chief physician prescribed rest. The decision will delay for at least the third time a repair mission to reconnect three vital solar panels.

results.abstract: Virginia Military Institute class of 2001, which will report on Aug 18, will include first women to join student body, as result of 1996 Supreme Court ruling that requires women to be admitted if school is to retain its state support; 32 of 460 incoming freshmen are women; they are causing a stir, as first women, if for no other reason than males at school are going to extremes to assure that despite changes, female 'rats' will be treated every bit as callously as male 'rats'; there is understanding on campus that just one ugly incident could change VMI in far more complicated ways than letting in women; photo (M)

headline.main: Military College Awaits Its First Female Cadets

results.snippet: For years, the grand statues of the school's most acclaimed sons, Stonewall Jackson and George C. Marshall, have stood vigil over campus grounds, silent witnesses to the annual reruns of tradition born 158 years ago.    And again this August, as in...
results.lead_paragraph: For years, the grand statues of the school's most acclaimed sons, Stonewall Jackson and George C. Marshall, have stood vigil over campus grounds, silent witnesses to the annual reruns of tradition born 158 years ago. And again this August, as in all those past, comes another class of freshmen to the Virginia Military Institute, most of them blindly eager to endure the time-honored indignities of first-year life as a ''rat.''

results.abstract: Next Russian crew on disabled Mir space station will carry out space walk in effort to assess and repair damage from collision with cargo ship (M)

headline.main: Next Mir Crew Will Tackle Space Walk Outside Station

results.snippet: The next crew on the disabled Mir will walk in space outside the orbiting station as part of an effort to assess and repair damage from its collision with a cargo ship, Russian space officials said today.    Officials had already planned an internal...
results.lead_paragraph: The next crew on the disabled Mir will walk in space outside the orbiting station as part of an effort to assess and repair damage from its collision with a cargo ship, Russian space officials said today. Officials had already planned an internal spacewalk into the ruptured Spektr module to reattach power cables disconnected after the crash. On a second space walk, outside the Mir, planned for late August or early September, astronauts will try to locate the hole in Spektr's wall.

results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 U.S. Study Criticizes China On Restraining Christianity In its report on persecution of Christian groups around the world, the State Department has criticized China for suppressing religious worship and urged President Boris Yeltsin of Russia to protect his country's newly gained religious freedom. A1

results.abstract: NASA says Comdr Wendy B Lawrence is too small for Russian space walk suits and will send Dr David A Wolf in her place to help repair Mir space station; may delay launch of space shuttle Atlantis to let him complete extra instruction in Russia (M)

headline.main: NASA Names a New Astronaut To Be Sent to Repair Mir Station

results.snippet: The next American astronaut in line for a tour aboard the troubled Russian space station Mir has been pulled from the mission because she is too small for the Russian space walk suits, NASA announced today.    The astronaut, Comdr. Wendy B. Lawrence...
results.lead_paragraph: The next American astronaut in line for a tour aboard the troubled Russian space station Mir has been pulled from the mission because she is too small for the Russian space walk suits, NASA announced today. The astronaut, Comdr. Wendy B. Lawrence of the Navy, had been scheduled to begin a four-month stay on the Mir in September, but will be replaced by her backup, Dr. David A. Wolf, because he will be able to act as a backup crew member for planned space walks to repair the damaged station, the agency said.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOPPELT, ELIZABETH J. (BEEBE)

results.snippet: DOPPELT-Elizabeth J. (Beebe). Age 51, a woman of exceptional warmth, imagination and courage, died July 29, after a twenty-one year battle with breast cancer. Born Elizabeth Beebe in Brooklyn, New York, Liz excelled at Lincoln High School and at...
results.lead_paragraph: DOPPELT-Elizabeth J. (Beebe). Age 51, a woman of exceptional warmth, imagination and courage, died July 29, after a twenty-one year battle with breast cancer. Born Elizabeth Beebe in Brooklyn, New York, Liz excelled at Lincoln High School and at Brooklyn College, and maintained a working knowledge of physics and chemistry. She spent every childhood summer at Camp Taconic in the Berkshire Mountains, building lifelong friendships there. Her early ambitions included becoming a ballerina or an astronaut. Instead, she became an entrepreneur, creating several successful businesses built on her fine eye for style and design. Liz's companies included Beaux Dangles (women's high-fashion accessories) and Really Lizzie (unique children's gifts). Most recently, she was the proprietor of GreenHouse of Winnetka, Illinois, an innovative shop specializing in antiques for rooms and gardens. She traveled the country pursuing unusual and fine objects for her customers and her home. Liz was generous to close friends and business acquaintances alike, and provided both knowledge and encouragement to many women who suffered with her disease. She was loving and wise for her children, Rachel and Adam; her husband, Neil, and her brother, Hank, all of whom survive her. She was unfailingly supportive to her family through every big and little crisis in their lives. Despite her illness, Liz had no bitterness or regrets about her own life, only good humor and enthusiasm for her next challenge. Her strength was extraordinary. With her courage, her ready wit and keen intellect, and especially her loving spirit, she enriched the lives of all who knew her.
